participants.participant: Hans Ola Meyer, Senior Vice President, Controlling and Finance
Gunnar Brock, President and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Hello. I have the honor to open this Q4 Presentation with Atlas Copco. And I now will leave over the speech to the moderator, the CFO of Atlas Copco, Hans Ola Meyer.

Thank you, Peri-Eric and heartily welcome to everybody here in Stockholm and everybody on the conference call, as well. We will follow the usual format. We have Gunnar Brock, our CEO, will make an introductory remark for about 20 minutes, and then we'll open up for questions-and-answer session after that.
So with that, I welcome you all again and I leave the word to Gunnar.

Thank you very much, Hans Ola, and good morning and good afternoon to everyone. We will try to keep this at around 20 minutes, and then it will be able – you will be able to put all the questions you would like to do. I will also refer, as customary procedure, to the PowerPoint slide numbers, so those of you who are not in this room can follow.

So, let us jump over to slide three immediately and try to put the highlight. Some said it should be lowlight, but when we are through with the presentation, I think in the end, I am very convinced that given the state of the world, it is really highlight.

Now, as you have seen, and I will touch on that more in numbers later on, the orders intake during the quarter, of course, dropped considerably, about 18%, organically, and then we add on the cancellations, particular within mining sector, but I'll come back to that.

The good thing, though, as we have said is that the aftermarket is still continuing to grow. And as we will count towards the end of this year, of course, the mix will be such that the aftermarket share of the total, barring a change in the demand situation, will of course be higher, and therefore that should sustain the margins.

We have, perhaps, not been too vocal, but those of you who know us, know also that we have a relatively short sort of distance to react. So, we have actually reduced the number of people during the last three months of the year with about 1,400 – close to 1,400. That means people have left the payroll, and who are no longer with us, and that has been possible through various actions. And that's not been in Sweden only, not at all, it's been in a global fashion. And finally, the Board just proposed, some hours ago, that we will keep the dividend unchanged to three krones per share.

Turning to the next slide, number four. Now, a little bit more in figures, what I just said verbally; 19% organic order intake drop, and if you add the cancellations, mainly in the Construction and Mining about 8%, it turned out to be 27. Revenues, as we have an order book and as we go into the first quarter of this year, we also have an order book, revenues grow by 3%.

The operating profit, just a little touch less than last quarter – same quarter 2007. However, if you add back the redundancy costs to 258, you will see a margin of 18% to be compared to 19.3. And I think this is pretty strong given what is happening, when you go from a sort of tremendous high-capacity utilization into a very, very abrupt sort of status.

Now, we were helped by the currency as you see. Hans Ola may give you a little more flavor to that later, but it also has to do with the financial net. Profit before tax, quite considerably above last year, one-time item of roughly 900 million Swedish krones relating to capital gain and repatriation of equity, Hans Ola may come back to that later as well. And that leaves us with a very high earnings per share, of course, for the quarter.

Cash flow turned out quite strong in the end and that to us is important. It is a combination, and I will come back to that, of operating cash flow from the business and some cash flow from the financial items.

Turning then to the world map, slide six. There you can see the geographic split of what I just said. These figures do contain the cancellations. So, the picture may not be as bleak as it looks here. If I take Compressor Technique, for instance, they had growth in South America, Africa and in Australia. So, they had a slightly better mix and substantially fewer, only 1 or 2% cancellations.

Not dwelling too much on this, going to the North America, I think we confirm what everybody else is confirming, the MVI, motor vehicle industry is not doing particularly well. General industry is doing relatively better, but still below last year. The mining industry, particularly coal, surface coal did contract quite a bit in the quarter.

Compressor business turned out pretty stable, and I think it has been better than expected, and quite a good performance actually. Perhaps, we are taking a little bit bigger slice of the cake as well. South America in the degree of misery, if you say, was actually not so bad. Brazil kept up very well until, I would say, December, when we also saw in Brazil what generally happened in other markets a bit earlier.

Turning then to slide eight, Europe, where about 9% of the business in Europe is, what we call, Eastern Europe and the rest is the traditional Europe and the Northern countries. Similar picture there, we saw, basically across countries and business, there are similar developments, and mining business actually quite weak in Russia as well. Africa, a bit better; Central Africa, doing well in the mining, actually; South Africa, doing relatively well, as well.

And then finally moving over to Asia, I think Japan, has been a troublesome market for many years, is ironically showing good figures, when the rest of Asia is showing less good figures. But I think the general backdrop in Japan has not improved, as you know, on the contrary. But I think we have done a few things to perhaps improve our positions.

China, India; China rather weak except in the construction business, where CMT, but partly also in mining has actually done quite well and we see actually growth figures in China in that area. We may come back to that later. And Australia, finally, having done relatively better than other mining countries. And Compressor Technique is doing very well in Australia.

So, that adds me up to the slide 10, and as Hans Ola said at beginning, it's the same procedure as every time. Unfortunately, it is not the same procedure, because for the first time the bar is showing the wrong direction. Our little graphic innovation, as you can see the colored part of the bar is the 18% organic decline, and then the transparent part of the bar refers to cancellations.

Speaking about cancellations, particularly in the mining business, they have been going on at a similar rate during the first quarter. But in January, we see a slowdown in the cancellations, so an improvement on that respect. I think as we normally show, the slide 11 on the organic, and organic and adding there acquisition growth, you can see that, of course, with the changes and with the cancellations the 2008 bar does not stand as tall as the other bars.

Coming over to the bridge, you can see to the left the orders received, the 8% cancellation, volume 22, price up three, so that together will be the organic of about 19%, nominally down 18. Currency, of course playing a role here, adding another 9 to the quarter figures, and for the year, it actually came out more or less without any impact.

Quickly going over to the business areas, if you look at the figures, the return on capital and the EBIT figures for the three business areas, you can see that 18.6% for the group of 2008, I think is still very strong given the difficulty everybody has to try to adapt to the last quarter of this year. Return on capital 34, if you add the customer finance business which now is starting to creep in, you should add 3, 4%, if we would take the rouse excluding the customer finance business.

Now we are on slide 15, I think, talking about the business areas, Compressor Technique in the quarter had about 15% lower order intake, and you could generally say it was to be seen in those parts and in those segments, barring what I said just a little while ago actually U.S. held up pretty well, and so did Australia but otherwise similar pattern.

I think if you add back the redundancy cost 21.4% EBIT in the quarter, I think is very strong, and I will say this and repeat this many time. We must remember that we went into the year, and it was records on every parameter until basically 1st of October. So with the difficulties you have – and I'll come back to that when I talk about flow through later on – you will see a, I think a very strong performance by Compressor Technique.
A small acquisition was made, hasn't been consumed in its entirety yet, because we are waiting for some anti-trust approval in one or two markets, but in several markets it has been approved.

And I will not dwell on slide 16, but that shows the graph over time, and as you can see although this revenue growth, we have still and of course, been able to keep a steady, steady earning capacity in different growth modes.

CMT, Construction and Mining Technique had, as we've said, the sharpest decline in the order intake, 16% of the order declined, over 27% was cancellations. Mainly mining, and as, I've said just a little while ago, the rate of cancellation has dropped considerably in January compared to the quarter.

Aftermarket as well in Compressor Technique as in CMT is growing steadily and if you take away the – or add back the redundancy cost of 100 million, you will see that, it was basically an unchanged EBIT margin. Yes, helped by currency EBIT, no question about that. But I think also the difficulty has been pretty big for CMT to adapt to the slowdown. I'll come back to that and here you see the graph on slide 18 or is it possibly 19 – 18.
Then moving over to the worst hit in terms of profit numbers, the Industrial Technique, where we're adjusting for the redundancy had a 16% profit margin.

Now, why do I say it's been the worst hit? Well, it is the business area of the three that has the most exposed anatomy, because basically, what you can say they have very high gross margins and very high functional costs.

So when revenue drops, it has a very quick impact on the profitability. So they are of course, fighting with a lot of redundancy and under absorption as well as adjustments. So it is not surprising and this has been shown in the past, when downturns have been even – or hasn't been as bad but you can see the effect. So there is nothing strange about that.

Then the mix vis-à-vis customers has been more of projects and less of components and we have seen – we've been buying and reselling more products as some of our customers really want us to take a bit bigger scope of supply and when you then add products that are not your own proprietary products you have, pretty low profitability on those.

So, let me then move over to the financials, slide 22. And I think it summarizes what I have said and I don't think I need to dwell on this anymore. We have talked about those figures before. Coming back to the flow through and I will basically talk about all three business areas at the same time so I just turn over to the next, which is 24.

I think there is nothing strange that the flow through is bad because what we've seen of course is a tremendous increase in capacity and activity for five years. And in a normal slowdown, these adjustments, they come gradually over time, but when you have such a sharp slowdown you have the adjustments. So that's under absorption, its warrantee and return and write-downs of spare parts. It is obsolescence. A lot of normal adjustments come all-in-one. So from this point of view, I am not concerned that the flow through hasn't been better. I think we have really sort of gathered a lot of since that has been building up during several years.

Now, there is nothing wrong about that what you would like to see perhaps it's a slower decline, so you don't bring out everything at once. We will of course not be free of this in Q1 either, but I think we have seen I would be surprised if we haven't seen the worst at least this quarter.

Balance sheet on slide 25, yes there is quite an inflation in the balance sheet but I think you could pretty quickly consolidate the figures between the previous periods and December by referring to currency as a major part, but also we have cash and other financial assets that are substantially higher and then also some deferred tax assets so when you add that together it is not – not terribly strange.
What we are seeing though and I'll show you that when we come to the cash flow figures in the wireless of course, a reduction in the working capital starting to take place.

Net debt to EBITDA, a little bit lower hardly though and that's of course been inflated by the currency. Hans Ola, I'm sure, will come back, but of course we have seen a really extremely unusual change in the dollar and particularly in the euro/Swedish krona rates and of course this has had an effect on our balance sheet, but Hans Ola will talk a bit more about that.

Perhaps to mention also that our loan maturity you've seen in the slide before is good, in addition to this we have very little outstanding in the outside the Atlas Copco AB about one billion spread in different countries and in different maturity rates. So, looking from this point of view, I think we have a very enviable perhaps profile.

Cash flow quite strong, which is important. We have been a little bit and particularly myself a bit I am patient that we haven't seen the reduction in working capital starting to take place until basically in the end of the period and as you can see here change in working capital it's been reduced by a bit over 100 million, than of course comparing with that same quarter the year before when we still grew the business we sort of invested another 800 in the working capital.

So as we go forward, no doubt the cash flow will start to come back in a good way. It does take several months before the inflow of components, before the work in progress, before the sales stock is really being sort of worked through. And if you have the cancellations of 16% like CMT, it is not easy to quickly adjust. So, impatience is good, but I think we will be rewarded as we go into this first quarter. But still a very good cash flow although as you can see some of it relating or is related to financial items.

Investments are a little bit higher. We are not investing unnecessarily today, but the investment decisions taken 2006, 2007 has of course trickled through, but you will also see a much reduced fixed assets investment to '09 compared to the figures you see here.

Moving, then over to the slide about dividends. As you can see here, some anomalies in the charts, but these are positive anomalies I think, so we are – don't excuse ourselves for that. We have maintained the dividend at three krona. We have and we believe we will have a good cash flow. We believe that the resilience in our business model will prevail even into '09, even taking care and taking into account potential acquisitions, but also a slightly lower tax rate going forward compared to earlier. I think we are prudently able and prepared to suggest an unchanged dividend.

Then looking at the summary, since most arrows have been pointing down so far. I think I could show at least one slide showing some arrows pointing upwards. And although we ended the 2008 on slightly misery or miserable note. I think, we still added almost two billion more to the profit, the operating profit. So I think that all-in-all it is perhaps as Hans Ola suggested it was a tough ending to a very good year.

And this is – sum it up here for the year as a whole, I will not read that. I think you can do that yourself. Slide 32 for those of you are on the phone lines. And then the outlook, which is pretty short and sustained, and I think that is basically what we see. I think there is one aspect that I'm sure you will ask about. And I think it is a positive ingredients looking at 2009, and that is the massive investment in infrastructure that almost every government around the world have proposed.

We see stabilization in the construction center. We see now we should not get carried away. But we see that this will most likely start to show as we work through the year, most of it will probably come in the second quarter. But as I said China is already actually pretty active in this sector. So I think the positive ending is that if there is anything that may surprise us particularly the second half year it is that sector.
So by that, I think, we close and leave the floor Hans Ola to the guests and the people on the line.
Thank you, Gunnar. We start the question-and-answer session, and before we actually get going, I think I ask the operator to repeat the instructions for question from the conference call.
Thank you sir. .

That was quick, so without further ado, I think we start here in Stockholm and we take two questions here and then we follow-up with two questions from the conference call. So we start here is there a microphone there? Yes.

Yes. Peder Frölén, Handelsbanken. A question about the cancellations, predominantly done in the mining field. Have you been very active in trying to get customers to cancel, are you not postponing their orders? And how you actually manage this, because it's a quite a significant number you're guiding about cancellation rates coming down?

It's a bit of an unusual question, because we don't normally have people who are skilled at calling the customers, saying please cancel your orders. And so, I think that where we have been very careful, but we have been that even before we saw the downturn. And that is to ask distributors, do you really have end customers? Are you really going to take the few orders? Because distributors are perhaps a bit more tactical sometimes, but they also have difficulty to pay for the equipment if they don't have an end user, who basically takes over the equipments. So there we have been trying to sort of sort out the potential cancellations.

When it comes to large mining companies, I think they have skillfully themselves called us and said they don't want the equipment or they want it postponed. I think that, most companies would rather say, we cancel the equipment rather than postponing, because it maybe a better position today to talk about cancellation fees, and penalties et cetera. We do have those in some cases, you can evoke them sometimes, sometimes you can not. But I mean, logically, the cancellation rate will go down as the order books will be more and more of a short-shelf and fresh.
And my second question, if I may, regarding your cost savings habit, quite a big number two billion, and could you please explain that a bit more in detail?

Well, it's actually a rather simple calculation, because if you add what we have done in Q4 and what has already been put in place to a very large extent for Q1 and Q2 this year. Just the number of employees not being on the payroll will add up to those sums. Then of course, we crosscheck with, what we call, functional costs and, of course, we are not only trying to save people, which is a rather miserable work and nobody is happy for every single person that has to leave, but we are also, of course, trying to reduce costs in other areas. But people are both part of the functional sales administration and marketing costs as well as they are part of the factories and the cost of goods.

So, if you add up, it's a rather realistic figure, no doubt, if by mid-year all those programs will have been enacted upon. And there you can – if you are pressing us on the redundancy or extraordinary restructuring costs, it is of course very difficult to say, because in some cases where we have given notification to people and you have six months of notice. In some cases, of course, there will be no redundancy costs because the people will stay on for the full period. In other cases, people will be asked to leave and then we will, of course, pay the residual amounts.

We don't – it's a difficult thing, because it's pretty demoralizing to have people staying on if there is no sensible work to be done. On the other hand, given the flexibility we have, if things should turned for a little bit better, then of course one wouldn't like to have seen qualified people leave. So, I think therefore it is difficult to give a very fair sort of month or quarterly. I think, the first half of the year will sort out. But the cost savings are, no doubt, of that magnitude, on a run rate from second half of next year, and we have seen, of course already, the last month.
Okay. I've two questions, a follow-up on the previous one. Among 3,000 people who leave the company, are there any temporary employees, so the easy targets you move first?

Yeah. I mean, out of those close to 1,400 that's left in the last three months of the year, there were a lot of the temporary employees. There are still temporary employees in some parts, but you know when you are working in 160, 70 (sic) [170] countries around the world, there are different rules in every country about what is a temporary employee and what is not. Countries like Belgium, where we have CET, as you know, there you can have a flexible system, where workers leave more or less immediately but you pay a fourth and the government pays three-quarter. In other countries, you have different arrangements.

So, yes, there are still left, people in the organization, who could be classified as temporary. Then we have consultants who are 100% occupied by us, but technically, not on our payroll, and they are over 1,000 people. So, there you have a -
Are they included in the 3,000 as well -
Yes, there are parts of those, not all of them. But, there are parts of those. Yeah.

Okay. My second question is regarding order intake. I guess the order intake has been even – not evenly spread during the third quarter that means that December should have been the worst month. And what do you see now in January? Should we expect another downturn in the order intake of the same magnitude or even worse, maybe?
When you talk about -

...rate of decline or the – no, I think you – I think that you will see a Q1 – you will not see an improvement on the contrary. I think if you take the Q4, it started off better, or relatively less good in October. And now I think we have to be very careful when drawing conclusions from December and January, because so many companies did not have any activities going on for several weeks or even six, seven weeks. We have a lot of companies, who didn't really start activities until end of January. We have the Chinese New Year making China pretty, sort of, passive as of 22nd, 23rd of January.

So, I think it's a little bit hard to use December and January as a guide. But, it's not looking – judging from that, it will not look better on the contrary. But I think we have to, and I think, we all have to see how February, March looks. There is a reduction in inventory in the manufacturing world. I'm not sure we have such a good hand on that and I think that companies like Caterpillar, the other day, showed how difficult it is for them to keep track even on their distributors to know the stock.

So, are our customers coming to the end where they can reduce inventories no more? I think, we don't really know that yet. But that is logically it's an issue of timing. Ones it is then we will see what the run rate is. But, I think it's very difficult to be too precise.
Thank you. We'll turn to the first question on the conference call then.
Thank you, sir. We'll take our next question now from Nico Dil of JP Morgan. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, gentlemen, Nico Dil from JP Morgan. Two quick questions please. First of all, on the lead times within the different divisions, just to get a feel of also, how far these cancellations can still keep up. Could you highlight what lead time is currently in CMT and CT? Second question is you highlighted that organic orders were down about 43% in CMT, how much of this was due to construction and what was due to mining?
Okay. Starting with the last question first. I mean the 43 included 19%. I think it was 19 or 16 cancellations, and I think the important thing is the run rate.

16, so take away 16 from the 43 to get some kind of run rate. The majority is mining. By far, the majority is mining. And in the new order intake, we can see a, as I alluded to earlier, shift towards more construction of the mix than mining. Lead times differs from different divisions. Gas and process, basically, has a full order book for the year. Their lead times are depending a bit on the type of equipment, relatively long still. Oil-free Air; couple of months, depending on the type of equipment. Most of the other comprehensive business, rather short, so be it for most of the CMT. There may be large special drill rigs that have a longer delivery time, but from stock to three to six months, depending on what we talk about.

Industrial technique has, of course, normally a components delivery where we basically shift from our distribution centers. So, there we have a very short lead time or a delivery time, larger system deliveries, a bit longer.
Thank you. Shall we take the second question, please?
Thank you. Our next question now comes from Arnaud Brossard from Exane. Please go ahead.

Hello. I have two questions. The first one would be on prices, and I would like it if you could comment on your view on pressure on prices in the next few months. My second question is on savings, and I would like to know if you could tell us when you expect these to be implemented in real effective savings?

Okay. I start from the back again. As I said, the – provided, as we stated in the report, the program is run as it's been put in place, you will see the run rate as of second half next year, but of course progressively. But again, this depends very much on the way we do this, whether people work the notice period or whether we sort of financially settle before that. But, all that aside from second half run rate should be in.

Prices is an interesting thing because, obviously, classic theory would argue that prices would be under a lot of pressure, and I think they are in general. However, I think that for us being who we are with our heritage, it's very important to keep prices at a desired level. And therefore, I think we will really aim at that going forward. And so far, we've managed well to keep our prices. But, there maybe pockets where things warrant more aggressiveness, but generally, there is a life after this. And therefore, we are going to maintain our prices as much as ever, ever possible.
Could you just detail a bit on what pockets are the weaknesses?

I think it – general pockets, it could easily be said. There may be countries where a particular competitor has a lot of stock. And they may – depending on who the competitor is, they may elect to try to be very aggressive on getting rid of that stock, which I think is pretty standard actually. Now, we are not going to do and act that way. Our stocks are moderate, and therefore, I think we don't have to. So therefore, I cannot say where and when, but in the global empire, I'm sure it's going to happen. But so to say, we will be very tough in trying to maintain a, and even positive, bridge component on price, but we will see.

Perhaps just to add to that you can already, in the fourth quarter report, see that there is a slight difference between the business areas that might also give the hint to that Industrial Technique has had slightly more challenging environment when it comes to prices and that's an indication that might also be carrying into 2009.

Perhaps I should add, Hans Ola, one thing on the prices and that is our product pipeline, our new product introduction is very good for the 2009. And of course, that is the most important way of trying to keep prices up when you introduce new products that are hopefully more performing and we have a religion that when we introduce new products they should always be lower to manufacture than the products they replace. And so far, I think we keep that pretty well. How that pans out, of course, in a market situation to what extent we will be really following or tactically delay product introductions, that is a tactical issue we will play case by case.
Okay. And just one last question. If demand remained at a low level, would you expect the pressure on prices to increase during the year or do you expect it to be stable?

I think the – generally, for any industry, generically, the pressure would increase. But it depends also on who is there to compete with you. And in the end, as I said again our heritage is not to be a price fighter, and as a market leader in most areas, I think it's pretty clear what we will try to do.
Thank you.
Thank you very much.
Thank you. We turn again to two questions here in Stockholm. We have one in the back there. If you please state your name before, it would be -

Mats Liss, Swedbank. Just a couple of questions; first, regarding orders, again. Well, the cancellations, have it – well, this – have it made you, well, stock up on finished goods that has to be distributed later on, or are you sort of free of those problems? And then secondly about the service, you in – service in aftermarket you indicate that the growth have continued during the fourth quarter, and I just wondered if that's quarter-by-quarter, or is it gradually during the quarter as well. So, you started out January on a pretty good note.

Okay. Where do we have stocks? I take Compressor Technique, not much, not that much. And I think again, it comes back to the different make-up of the divisions as well as the way we are producing, because we are not producing at full stock, no but we produce that – So, I think that is not a sizable problem. CMT, there are in some areas for drill rigs, surface drill rigs, there are a bit of sales stock. But, what you can do is you can rebuild those, not all of them. In some cases, you have to wait for the order, but in some cases you can decide whether you want to rebuild them for a respect that is more current. But in the other area, it is not that much easy.

Industrial Technique, we have – for most of the product, we have launched distribution center in Europe which is sort of more or less delivering out of stock. And there, of course, we are gradually reducing that, but it takes of course a bit of time. And IT, as I said earlier, it's the business area that is hit the hardest, the fastest, because of the high gross margins and high cost levels, which means they will have a lot of under absorption and adjustments. Aftermarket, yeah, I'd – aftermarket is aftermarket and consumables, particularly for, well all three business areas have consumables, but particularly CMT. It's been a growth, but the growth has been a bit small, lower in – let's say in the second half than in the first half, but it's still a relatively good growth.
Okay, we have another question.
And just one -
Go, sorry.
More regarding Compressor Technique. Well, is the slowdown in that market, will it make you sort of speed-up the in-house use of your own compressor elements?

Well, yeah. Yeah, you are right. I mean, basically today, most of it will be done in-house this year. There may be not exactly 100% fit between our capacity to machine parts for certain rotors, because in the end you cannot change the mix in the manufacturing of rotors from one day to another. You have to take a bet on what will be the mix going forward a bit. But yes, we will do most of it ourselves. That will be very little outside.
Second question, yes?

Johan Trocmé from Nordea Markets. Gunnar, at the Capital Markets Day on the 4th (sic) [2nd] of December, you mentioned that you didn't want to cut back adapting to the coming downturn in research and development, and that the next area for review in scaling back could be those additional feet in the street in covering markets better, particularly in emerging markets. Will people in that part of the organization be part of this next wave of downsizing, or are you trying to maintain that effort?

And the second question, if I could just add on straight away, may be for Hans Ola, could you just describe to us a little bit in what you did in the repatriation of overseas equity, which led to this capital gain? And is there anything more to be expected there that we should be aware of going forward?

Okay. Yes, we said in early December at the Capital Markets Day, there are two areas we will not scale back. R&D, because; one, the people are difficult to find, and if you let them go, they may not want to come back; secondly, it's pretty – I think it's pretty downright stupid to save 0.5% on R&D costs. There is a life after this downturn. And if you want to – if you can afford and we can afford to spend on those, we will. So, there will be no saving.

The other area is aftermarket. We will not save anything in the aftermarket provided there is business, but it's a pretty simple decision, because it's a rather variable cost. If we get a service contract, we will deal with that. If we have service contracts that are cancelled, we will not have the resources staying with us. So, I think in that respect, we will be able to take whatever aftermarket growth and opportunities there are.

And if I look then at feet in the street generally, I mean, yes, we are scaling back even some feet in the street in the world. There is no doubt about that. But, the – if you go back and look at the business volume we had a couple of years ago and look at the resources we had then, I think it would be strange if we with the resources we will have this year will not be able to take the business that's there.

I mean, CMT has gone for and I think if my memory serves me right, 7 billion Swedish krones of turnover 2003 to 32 – Hans Ola slaps me if I'm wrong, 32, I think in 2008, and we've had a lot of resources. So, no doubt we will be able to fight for whatever business there is out there with even a substantially slimmed down company.

Thank you. When it comes to the repatriation of euro, I perhaps should start with an overriding comment that in this quarter we have seen, by far, the most dramatic currency changes vis-à-vis the Swedish Krona in such a short period as far back as the big devaluation in 1992, perhaps. And that causes effects, not only in the financial net that you mentioned Johan, it causes effects that are difficult to predict and to project the size of them also in the cash flow statement and also in the balance sheet.

So, this is sort of that type of a quarter, if I start with that. What we did was following the capital structure – restructuring of 2007, we have a very large internal equity, internal capital in euro land; in Belgium and in Luxemburg. This is a capital that is tested for market value, so it's our operations value in short.

Now, what we did in December was that we brought back some of that capital to Sweden. And the – in order not to have a large currency exposure, we also had that capital, to a large extent, hedged by means of internal loans between euroland and Sweden in that case. Now, we have gone from a euro to Swedish krona rate of about 9 to 950, when this capital was put in place in 2007, and now we repatriated portion of it at close to 11 to the Swedish krona. So, that's been a tremendous change.

In this structure, we can have a tax deductible currency loss on the loan that is not matched by the gain that we make on the repatriation or the dividend that we take from euro, meaning, basically that we have a tax-free gain of this 940 million. We have a more capital in euroland. Is there any plans to reduce that? Well, we look into the capitalization of the group continuously, and particularly in situation where there are tax changes in Sweden, as you know, coming up. Both, the income tax is going to change from 28 to 26.3, next year, there are new rules on the possibility to deduct internal interest between companies, and at the same time, we look at how big value in terms of euro – in terms of Swedish krona do we carry, just because of the exchange rate, and we make an assessment.

So, I cannot predict that there will not be more changes to that structure that might eventually lead to results of a similar nature that we have seen this time. But it was a very, very specific quarter and the magnitude became very big for that reason. So, the main message is perhaps that, yes, it is a realized event, but at the same time, we cannot build it into any forecast, we cannot predict it for the future.

On the same token, there was also a mentioning in the report that in our cash flow, we also had a positive effect of similar – related to the same basic topic that we have to bring certain internal deposits into Sweden. And again, when we hedge that to the Swedish krona, we have realized big gains on that hedging. And that is also only a cash-flow effect, though, and that's what we refer to as being a result of hedge transactions, when it comes to the cash flow as well.

And finally, Gunnar also mentioned when you saw the balance sheet that also there, of course, there are huge translation effect that will not be realized over the income statement just because of the tremendous strengthening of the euro or the weakening of the Swedish krona, I should probably say.
